leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.12] r 15.12 Particulars required for proceedings generally (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(2)–(5))

leg:heading.title: Particulars required for proceedings generally (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(2)–(5))

p.text: This rule applies to a claim for damages in respect of personal injuries arising from any event (the accident), other than a claim that is the subject of proceedings under the Compensation to Relatives Act 1897.

On or as soon as practicable after serving the statement of claim, the plaintiff must serve on the defendant, or on the defendant’s insurer or solicitor, a statement accompanied by the following documents:
copies of all documents available to the plaintiff in support of a claim for special damage and economic loss, whether past, present or continuing, including:
hospital, medical and similar accounts, and
letters from a workers’ compensation insurer indicating moneys paid to or for the plaintiff, and
letters from employers, wage records, income records and group certificates, and
reports, award rates and correspondence relied on to support any claim in respect of domestic assistance or attendant care,
copies of all hospital and medical reports available at the time of serving the statement on which the plaintiff intends to rely at the hearing.
On or as soon as practicable after serving the statement required by subrule (2), the plaintiff must file a copy of that statement (without the accompanying documents required by this rule).
[subr (2A) insrt Amendment 30 of 2009 Sch 1[3], effective 11 December 2009]
The statement must set out the following particulars:
particulars of injuries received,
particulars of continuing disabilities,
particulars of out-of-pocket expenses.
If the statement makes any claim in respect of domestic assistance or attendant care, it must also set out full particulars of the claim.
If the statement makes any claim in respect of loss of income, it must also set out the following particulars:

the name and address of each employer during the 12 months immediately before the accident, together with details of the periods of employment, capacity in which employed and net earnings during each period of employment,
the name and address of each employer since the accident, together with details of the periods of employment, capacity in which employed and net earnings during each period of employment,

the amount claimed in respect of loss of income to the date of the statement (by comparison between what the plaintiff has earned since the accident and what the plaintiff would have earned but for the accident) setting out, in respect of what the plaintiff would have earned but for the accident, including, where appropriate:
particulars of the earnings of comparable employees and the identity of those employees, or
particulars of any payment that the plaintiff would have received under a relevant award or industrial agreement, together with the title of that award or industrial agreement,
particulars of any alleged loss of earning capacity and future economic loss,

if the plaintiff is self-employed or has been self-employed at any time during the 12 months immediately before the accident, such additional particulars as will achieve full disclosure of the basis of the claim for loss of income.
If the statement makes any claim in respect of loss of income, copies of the following documents must be served on all active parties:
a letter from the employer or employers (if any) of the plaintiff immediately before the accident the subject of the proceedings, providing particulars of:
the dates on which the plaintiff was absent from work due to the accident, and
the total net remuneration lost by the plaintiff in respect of that absence, including overtime, and
if the plaintiff returned to work for that employer, the plaintiff’s classification and duties, and any alteration in the remuneration paid to the plaintiff, after that return, and
if that employment has been terminated, the date of and reason for the termination,

if the plaintiff was self-employed immediately before the accident, copies of any accountants’ reports or other documents on which the plaintiff intends to rely to establish his or her pre-accident income,

copies of the plaintiff’s income tax returns relating to income received during the period of 2 financial years ending immediately before the financial year that included the date of the accident, together with copies of any income tax returns lodged by the plaintiff since the date of the accident.
[subr (6) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[13], effective 8 December 2006]
If any, or any part of, any document required to be served by subrule (6) cannot be served, a statement of the reasons why it cannot be served must be included in the documents served.
The approved form is Form 14 : Statement of Particulars — Personal Injuries Proceedings.

This rule complements the general requirement to give particulars in personal injury cases. It applies generally to personal injury claims and includes those relating to intentional torts: Styles v Clayton Utz (No 3) (2011) 255 FLR 364; [2011] NSWSC 1452; BC201109149 at [221]–[222]. Nevertheless, claims that have not been particularised in compliance with this rule may still be recovered if there is evidence to support them. The overriding principles of permitting such claims is one of fairness in the conduct of the trial: Nestle Australia Ltd v McDougall (NSWCA, 24 June 1998, unreported, BC9802626) (claim for future out of pocket expenses permitted although not particularised). The requirement to provide copies of all medical reports intended to be relied upon does not require a plaintiff to provide, in effect, discovery of all their medical treatment records. It has been held, for example, that a request in a personal injury case for particulars of the plaintiff’s “pre-accident and post-accident treating doctors” and, in the case of pre-accident treating doctors, for particulars of those doctors “for the period of five years prior to the date of the accident” is in the “nature of a fishing expedition falling well outside the function of particulars as established by authority”: Bellamy v Bennett [1999] NSWSC 912; BC9905708 .

level.toc-caption: [15.12.15] Proceedings for contribution or indemnity in relation to liability for personal injury

p.text: Legislation cited in [15.12.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 21, Pt 22, r 15.12, rr 21.3, 21.8, r 22.1.
(NSW) Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 151Z, s 151Z(1)(d).
(NSW) Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 40.

heading.title: Proceedings for contribution or indemnity in relation to liability for personal injury

p.text: UCPR r 15.12 does not apply to proceedings for indemnity or contribution in relation to liability for personal injury: Westpac Banking Corporation v Tomassian (1993) 32 NSWLR 207; BC9304094 (indemnity claim under Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 151Z(1)(d) is not a claim for damages in respect of the death of, or injury to, a person within Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 40 ); Allianz Australia Insurance Ltd v Newcastle Formwork Constructions Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 144; BC200704837 (appeal from District Court dismissal of notice of motion seeking order for answers to request for particulars in indemnity proceedings under Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 151Z , appeal dismissed); New South Wales (Ambulance Service of NSW) v McKitterick [2009] NSWCA 63; BC200902010 (indemnity claim under Workers Compensation Act 1987 s 151Z(1)(d) )

A party claiming indemnity or contribution for such a liability should, nevertheless, provide sufficient particulars to permit the defendant to know the case it has to meet in relation to its original potential liability to the injured person: Allianz Australia Insurance Ltd v Newcastle Formwork Constructions Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 144; BC200704837 at [23] ; Jawa Group Pty Ltd v Tatana (NSWDC, Garling DCJ, 12 April 2005, unreported); Kurnell Passenger and Transport Service Pty Ltd v Randwick City Council [2009] NSWCA 59; BC200901711 at [42] . Furthermore, because indemnity proceedings are not personal injury proceedings, a defendant in those proceedings is potentially entitled to discovery under UCPR Pt 21 ( rr 21.3 , 21.8 ) and interrogatories under UCPR Pt 22 ( r 22.1 ): New South Wales (Ambulance Service of NSW) v McKitterick [2009] NSWCA 63; BC200902010 at [8] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.13] r 15.13 Particulars required for proceedings under Compensation to Relatives Act 1897 (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(6) and (7))

leg:heading.title: Particulars required for proceedings under Compensation to Relatives Act 1897 (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(6) and (7))

p.text: This rule applies to a claim for damages in respect of personal injuries arising from any act, neglect or default (the accident) that is the subject of proceedings under the Compensation to Relatives Act 1897.
On or as soon as practicable after serving the statement of claim, the plaintiff must serve on the defendant, or on the defendant’s insurer or solicitor:
in respect of each person on whose behalf the proceedings are commenced, a statement containing the following information:
the person’s name, address, relationship to the deceased person the subject of the proceedings, marital status and any anticipated alteration to that status,

whether the person’s dependency on the deceased person, or the person’s reliance on services provided by the deceased person, is claimed to have been whole or partial, the circumstances in which the person received support or services from the deceased person, and the quantum of that support or those services during the 12-month period immediately before the death of the deceased person, and
in respect of each person on whose behalf the proceedings are commenced, copies of the following documents:
a copy or extract of the person’s birth certificate and, if the person has been married, a copy of the person’s marriage certificate,

copies of any bank statements, financial records or other documents on which the person intends to rely to establish the extent of the support and other benefits provided to the person by the deceased person, covering a period of not less than 12 months immediately before the date of the death of the deceased person, and
in respect of the deceased person, copies of the following documents:

a letter from the employer (if any) of the deceased person immediately before the accident, providing particulars of the deceased person’s remuneration and prospects of promotion at the date of his or her death,

copies of the deceased person’s income tax returns relating to income received during the period of 2 financial years ending immediately before the financial year that included the date of his or her death,
copies of all documents, including accounts and receipts, in support of any claim for the cost of a funeral or headstone or for any other expenses relating to the deceased person’s death,
copies of documents evidencing the net value of the estate of the deceased person.
[subr (2) subst Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[14], effective 8 December 2006]
On or as soon as practicable after serving the statement required by subrule (2), the plaintiff must file a copy of that statement (without the other documents required to be served by this rule).
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 30 of 2009 Sch 1[4], effective 11 December 2009]
If any, or any part of, any document required to be served by subrule (2) cannot be served, a statement of the reasons why it cannot be served must be included in the documents served.
The approved form is Form 15 : Statement of Particulars — Compensation to Relatives Proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.14] r 15.14 Statements, documents and reports to be complete (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(8)–(10))

leg:heading.title: Statements, documents and reports to be complete (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(8)–(10))

p.text: The statement and documents required by rule 15.12 or 15.13 to be served:
must be as final and complete as to the plaintiff’s case as they can, with the exercise of reasonable diligence, be made, and
must contain such information as the plaintiff can then provide as to any medical examination of the plaintiff to be conducted after the date of service.

As soon as practicable after becoming aware that any information contained in a statement or document that has been served as required by rule 15.12 or 15.13 is no longer accurate and complete as regards the plaintiff’s claim, the plaintiff must give to all active parties such advice as is necessary to make that information accurate and complete.
If the plaintiff gives advice as referred to in subrule (2), the court may direct the plaintiff to file an amended statement of particulars.
Unless the court orders otherwise, the plaintiff must file a copy of the final statement of particulars at least 42 days prior to the date fixed for hearing or arbitration of the proceedings.
Subject to subrules (3) and (4), an amended statement of particulars may not be filed except by leave of the court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.15] r 15.15 Provision of schedule of documents and reports (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(10A))

leg:heading.title: Provision of schedule of documents and reports (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(10A))

p.text: [r 15.15 rep Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[15], effective 8 December 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.16] r 15.16 Effect of failure to comply with Division (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(11))

leg:heading.title: Effect of failure to comply with Division (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(11))

p.text: If, after conducting a review or status conference or otherwise, the court is of the opinion that the plaintiff has not sufficiently complied with the requirements of this Division, the court may dismiss the proceedings or make such other order as it thinks fit.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.17] r 15.17 Division not to apply in certain circumstances (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(1))

leg:heading.title: Division not to apply in certain circumstances (cf DCR Part 9, rule 27(1))

p.text: This Division does not apply to a claim that is accompanied by:
a notice of motion seeking a separate trial on the question of liability, or
a notice of motion seeking an order to defer the application of this Division to the proceedings.
